narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: I think a course like this needs to be continued in the future at FES. There is no other class offered that is geared towards the finance aspects of land management.
Lloyd Irland is great. A terrific teacher and very passionate about the subject. I am really sorry that he will not be around for future FES students.

It is truly unfortunate that Professor Irland will no longer be at FES next year, and that this course will no longer be taught. This course fulfills a huge need for students interested in managing land and resources who require an introduction to financial analysis. The economics courses do not fulfill this need, because they are based on more general economic theories, and they do not provide a grounding in the tools of analysis that an individual would use to gauge the financial viability of a specific project.I hope that the dean and other decision-makers will think seriously about this and that they will try to develop some alternative that will address this critical need.
Although a difficult class, the material is extremely important for MF students. The course should not be canceled!
I am very glad I took this course. I think it's critical to know something about how resources and land is valued, especially for an MF like me.

This is probably the best class I've taken at FES - it made everything I learned in Silviculture come together with the real world and brought out so many of the actual constraints of land management that mostly get ignored at FES. This was a key class for me and it's absolutely incomprehensible that it won't be offered next year.
the assignments
Examples and homework.
Practical use and run through of real life financial analysis and techniques.
The best thing was certainly homework that allows students to get the insights behind the lecture

This course is grounded in specific case studies, which makes it practical and real, but at the same time it also presents a toolkit for financial analysis that is much more broadly relevant to other situations and can be transferred easily.
The lectures of varied and interesting topics.

Lloyd brought big, difficult topics to the class, like the productivity of plantations or pricing carbon. There's far more diversity of opinion in the forestry community outside of Yale than there is within Yale, and I think Lloyd did us an important service in raising controversial topics.

The instructor - Lloyd clearly loves teaching and was the most accessible, most interested, and most enthusiastic professor I had this semester. He clearly went above and beyond the call of duty, and was very understanding of our interests and concerns.The assignments were key to the learning process in this class, as much as we suffered while completing them - without them, we wouldn't have learned anywhere near as much.The field trip to Maine was the best part of the semester to me - I learned more in 4 days than I have in months of studying! Also, it made me fall in love with Maine. Thanks!

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: sometimes I thought the lectures were a little too far off from what we were learning in the assignments.
Sometimes the lectures went well above and beyond financial analysis. While they were extremly intertesting, often times we really got off topic.
The class is more focused on the US environment for international students
The connection between the homework and the lectures.
There needs to be some way for forestry students to get financial analysis now that Lloyd can't come back.
Timing - 8.30 am is just too early for me!

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: They were great and responded eagerly
both were excellent
Help from TA and Instructor were excellent. They were always there when you needed them.
the TA was available at the TA hours, but not flexible to get the student off the hook when necessary. Her help was sometimes relevant.
Both were very helpful.
Top notch. The TA was most helpful and patient.
Elyzabeth was excellent. She explained concepts very well and had ample office hours, especially at the beginning of the semester (there were a few times she canceled toward the end).

Excellent - Lloyd was extremely helpful and made himself very available to questions/concerns. Also, he let me pick his brain for hours in Maine, without complaining once.Elyzabeth put in a huge amount of time and preparation, and her office hours were an essential part of getting the homework done. She clearly explained the assignments and was even willing to help us outside her office hours - repeatedly.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: This course is essential for any professional coming out of FES. It (in some form) should be mandatory for all MEM and MF students.
I am interested to see how this course complements/compares to conservation finance
it is an essential part of the MF program, and there is no duplicate for it.
Essential to it!
The course fits my overall program in forestry as it provides me with new skills and knowledge about the financial analysis with respect to forestry.
This course comprises my only introduction to financial analysis, and thus provides a good complement to my other courses which are more ecologically, socially, and politically oriented.
I need to know about finance if I ever want to run my own tree farm or sugarbush.
I'm an MF and I want to work in forest management or land conservation.

This class really brought into focus the things I've learned in Silviculture and Ecological Restoration. Taking these classes without a financial analysis class really just doesn't make a lot of sense - dreaming up treatments and management regimes is easy, but making them feasible is the important part. This class gave me a good context of markets for wood, and gave me an understanding of the relevant factors involved in landowner decision-making. This class is key for my future as a professional in the forestry and conservation sector.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Beacuse I am interested in financing conservation
to learn about how finances work in land management and to learn the tools I will use in my own career
I needed some basic knowledge of business and economics

Because of the Instructor. He and I had collaborated on some work before, and I felt like I could learn more from him. I also reealized I needed some financial analysis basics in order to be a competent manager in the future.
I took this course because I wanted to acquaint myself with financial analysis skills.
See question 15.
Fulfilled requirement and I wanted to know more about the topic.
See Q. 15. Also, Lloyd was very convincing at the course expo in 2009, and now I had all the necessary requirements together.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: yes
yes
definitely
Yes, the course totally live up my expectations, even I am not sure to have totally grasped the nitty-gritty.
Yes, it did.
I am not confident I could do an Excel financial analysis on my own.
Absolutely!

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: yes
Yes and no
yes
I would have expected more, but I believe the time allotted to this class was the major constraint.
Yes.
Yes!

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: I didn't participate in any group work
Mostly advantages. We collaborated and helped each other on problem sets. It also greatly helped walking through problems together so we could discuss things and better understand them.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Be proficient in excel prior to taking the class
realize that there is a lot of homework in the first 2/3 of the semester but it is all worth it
Be ready to dedicate quite a bit of time to this class. Especially on the homework problems.
To be prepared in advance for their final project and give time to read the book.
Lobby to have this course offered in the future!
Work in groups.
I wish they could take this class - it was a core class for me at FES. Bring back financial analysis!!!
